Is there a constant $c>0$ such that every graph on $2^n$ vertices with minimum degree $>(1-c)2^n$ contains the $n$-dimensional hypercube $Q_n$?



Erd\H{o}s \cite{Er93} says 'if the conjecture is false, two related problems could be asked':
{UL}
{LI}Determine or estimate the smallest $m>2^n$ such that every graph on $m$ vertices with minimum degree $>(1-c)2^n$ contains a $Q_n$, and {/LI}
{LI}For which $u_n$ is it true that every graph on $2^n$ vertices with minimum degree $>2^n-u_n$ contains a $Q_n$.{/LI}
{/UL}

See also [576] for the extremal number of edges that guarantee a $Q_n$.




References


[Er93] Erd\H{o}s, Paul, Some of my favorite solved and unsolved problems in graph
theory. Quaestiones Math. (1993), 333-350.


Back to the problem

proven: Complete graph on 2^n vertices contains Q_n
open: Main conjecture: ∃ c>0 for min degree threshold
If false: find smallest m>2^n that works
If false: find u_n for 2^n - u_n threshold

knowledge.progressSummary: SURVEYED: Proved hypercube_regular (n-regularity) and complete_contains_hypercube. Formalized conjecture and all basic properties.
builtItems: hypercube definition (Adj iff differ in 1 coordinate)
insights: Q_n = {0,1}^n with adjacency iff Hamming distance 1
Regularity proof: bijection between neighbors and coordinates
Embedding proof: use Fintype.equivOfCardEq for (Fin n → Bool) ≃ Fin 2^n
Conjecture: ∃ c>0 such that min deg > (1-c)·2^n → contains Q_n
If false, two alternative questions proposed by Erdős
Related to problem #576 (edge extremal for Q_n)
Lower bound: min degree 2^(n-1) may not suffice
nextSteps: Research known partial results on the conjecture
